thread.title: Carter denied jersey change, will wear white at Fulton
thread.title_full: Carter denied jersey change, will wear white at Fulton - PrepXtra Story

author: Chris Thomas
title: Carter denied jersey change, will wear white at Fulton
text:
The jersey switching will be limited to one team at Fulton High School on Friday.
Fulton's football team will wear light pink jerseys during its Week 7 home game against Carter as part of Farm Bureau's "Pink Out" series, which aims to promote the American Cancer Society's "Making Strides Against Breast Cancer" campaign.
Carter reluctantly will wear white instead of its contrasting home green jersey, thanks to a National Federation of State High School Association rule that assesses a 15-yard unsportsmanlike conduct penalty to visiting teams choosing not to wear white.
"The rule book says the home team must wear a color," TSSAA spokesman Matthew Gillespie said on Thursday. "The away team has to wear white. They can take the 15-yard penalty, of which Fulton could deny, but it would count as unsportsmanlike conduct against Carter. But that means if Carter's coach gets another, he'd have to miss a game."
Fulton coach Rob Black asked the TSSAA to make an exception on Thursday, but the request was denied.
"You don't want a coach under that kind of pressure if (Carter coach Jeff McMillan is) assessed an unsportsmanlike conduct penalty out of the gate," Black said. "I talked to an official on Monday who said they'd have to flag them for it."
Jersey switches aren't new. The Farm Bureau series began in 2013, and includes 32 games this year.
A team will wear pink in every one of them.
Last season, Carter wore pink for a game against Grainger, which wore blue instead of white, but no penalty was assessed for the tedious violation.
Halls and Gibbs, which play at Halls on Friday, traditionally wear their home jerseys during their game, but were not flagged to start last season's meeting.
"I don't see what the big deal is," Halls coach J.D. Overton said. "In the regular season, I don't see what it matters as long as they are contrasting colors and the coaches agree on it."
Venue Switch: Concord Christian will play Friday's home football game against Hancock County at Catholic High School, due to subpar field conditions.
"We normally play at (Mayor) Bob Leonard Park," Concord Christian coach Troy Fleming said. "But with the condition of the field and expected rain, the city wouldn't let us play on it. Fortunately, Catholic has an away game and was gracious enough to let us use their field."
The game is the first for Hancock since quarterback Dakota Blevins died in a single-car accident on Saturday.
Concord Christian, which forfeited its game last week due to concussion protocols, is expected to have enough players against Hancock.
Geer Picks Carson-Newman: Bearden girls basketball senior wing Chanler Geer committed to Carson-Newman on Tuesday, choosing the Eagles over King. She also had late interest from Tennessee Tech.
"They were a really good fit for me," said Geer, an All-KIL selection as a junior. "I went up there and visited a couple times, and liked the campus and atmosphere. They're a top Division II program. I respected that a lot."
Bearden Clinches District: Bearden's girls soccer team clinched a regular-season District 4-AAA title on Wednesday by tying Hardin Valley 2-2.
Casey Riemer scored both goals for the Lady Bulldogs, who have enjoyed a renaissance season.
Bearden (11-2-2, 6-0-1 District 4-AAA) didn't lose in district play this season, and beat traditional power Farragut for the first time since 2010 on Sept. 24.
Bearden plays at Oak Ridge on Thursday, and has non-district games scheduled against Science Hill, Catholic and McMinn County before beginning district tournament play on Oct. 10.
Other regular-season soccer champions include Powell (3-AAA), South-Doyle, which clinched a District 2-AAA title by beating Jefferson County 3-2 on Thursday, and Christian Academy of Knoxville (4-A/AA).
Grace Christian and Gatlinburg-Pittman are the top seeds in bi-divisional District 3-A/AA.
Greeneville has clinched a regular season title in District 2-A/AA.
Volleyball Top Seeds: Farragut (District 4-AAA), Anderson County (3-AAA), Morristown West (2-AAA), Catholic (4-AA), Gatlinburg-Pittman (3-AA), Greeneville (2-AA) and Jellico (4-A), Concord Christian (3-A) and Berean Christian (2-A) have clinched regular-season district titles and are the No. 1 seeds heading into next week's district tournaments.
